title: 112_hr3139
content: The Act may be cited as the "District of Columbia National Disaster Insurance Protection Act" and establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds. The Act establishes the District of Columbia Natural Disaster Protection Funds, allowing qualified contributions to a natural disaster protection fund to be included in the taxable income of insurance companies. The amendment to section 832 of the Code introduces a special rule for assets held in a natural disaster protection fund, excluding income, gain, loss, or deduction from being considered for gross income. Additionally, distributions from these funds are subject to specific modifications under section 832(b) of the Code. The amendment to section 832 of the Code introduces a special rule for assets held in a natural disaster protection fund, excluding income, gain, loss, or deduction from being considered for gross income. Distributions from these funds are subject to specific modifications under section 832(b) of the Code, including a provision for returning non-qualified contributions before filing the tax return. The amendment to section 832 of the Code introduces a special rule for assets held in a natural disaster protection fund, excluding income, gain, loss, or deduction from being considered for gross income. The term 'natural disaster protection fund' refers to money, securities, or property held by a qualified insurance company in a segregated account. The natural disaster protection fund is designated to be held in a bank in the District of Columbia and must be invested in compliance with investment requirements for insurance companies. The natural disaster protection fund, held in a bank in the District of Columbia, must comply with investment requirements for insurance companies. An excess balance drawdown amount must be distributed to the qualified insurance company by the close of the following taxable year, and no assets from the fund can be paid out except for a qualified distribution. A qualified insurance company, incorporated and domiciled in the District of Columbia, subject to supervision by the District of Columbia Commissioner of Insurance, Securities, and Banking, and maintaining an office with specific employee requirements. A qualified insurance company in the District of Columbia is subject to premium taxes, fees, and additional taxes imposed by the District of Columbia on domestic insurance companies. This includes taxes on premiums for natural catastrophic risk coverage written through the fund at a rate set by the District of Columbia. The term 'qualified contribution' refers to a contribution to a fund established by a qualified insurance company in the District of Columbia, not exceeding the Federal excise tax rate on reinsurance premiums. The term 'qualified distribution' refers to any payment made for a qualified loss insured through a fund, after considering all contributions, earnings, and reinsurance. The term 'qualified distribution' includes payments for qualified losses insured through a fund, such as payments for insurance or reinsurance, excess balance drawdown amounts, administrative expenses, and claims investigation and adjustments. The term 'qualified loss' refers to an insured loss on a United States risk caused by events like wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, or tidal wave. The term 'qualified loss' refers to an insured loss on a United States risk caused by events like wind, earthquake, flood, tsunami, volcanic eruption, fire, hail, snow, ice, freezing, winter catastrophes, pandemic, or other public health catastrophe. Insured losses must meet certain criteria for catastrophe designation or minimum aggregate insured loss. The criteria for a catastrophe designation include insured losses exceeding $1,000,000,000 industry-wide, a disaster declaration by the President, or a state of emergency declared by a Governor or chief executive of a State, possession, or territory of the United States. The term 'excess balance drawdown amount' refers to the surplus of the fund balance at the end of a catastrophic industry-wide loss event declared by a State, possession, or territory of the United States, or by the President or a Governor. The term 'United States risk' refers to hazards, risks, losses, or liabilities related to property or activities in the United States or its territories. Exclusion of premiums and losses on Puerto Rican risks covered by a catastrophe reserve established under Puerto Rico's laws or regulations shall not be considered in determining qualified contributions or losses. Contributions in kind to a fund are treated as a sale or exchange at fair market value. The Secretary shall prescribe regulations regarding distributions of property from a fund to a qualified insurance company, treating it as a sale or exchange with any gain or loss excluded from the gross income of the company. The Secretary will prescribe regulations for distributions from a natural disaster protection fund to insurance companies. A tax on nonqualified distributions will be imposed on qualified insurance companies. The tax imposed on qualified insurance companies for nonqualified distributions from a natural disaster protection fund will be increased by 20 percent of the total amount of such distributions made during the year. The bill's amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, with definitions of 'qualified insurance company' and 'natural disaster protection fund' as per section 832(h).
